results.title: Xin Xing, Giant Panda With Progeny Around the Globe, Dies at 38
results.abstract: The star of China’s Chongqing Zoo was the world’s oldest panda in captivity. More than 150 of her descendants have lived in several countries.

multimedia.caption: Xin Xing with a “birthday cake” at the zoo in Chongqing, China, in August. She used to eat seven meals a day, zoo keepers said.

results.title: Four Charged Over Blaze That Devastated Australia’s Fraser Island
results.abstract: The police said the men started an illegal campfire, but experts said the region would remain vulnerable to more fires as climate change worsens dry conditions.

results.title: Trial of High-Dose Blood Thinners in I.C.U. Patients Is Halted
results.abstract: Giving anticoagulants to hospitalized Covid-19 patients is routine. But high doses may sometimes do more harm than good, a safety board finds.

results.title: Can Travel Bans Really Stop the Spread of Coronavirus Variants? Experts Are Skeptical
results.abstract: It isn’t clear how widely the new variants are already circulating. So the latest moves by countries to bar international travelers may once again be too little, too late.

multimedia.caption: The closed port at Dover, England, on Monday as many European nations blocked arrivals from Britain because of a coronavirus variant there.

results.title: Pulse Oximeter Devices Have Higher Error Rate in Black Patients
results.abstract: A study showed that the devices, which measure oxygen levels in the blood, were three times more likely to give misleading readings among African-American patients.

multimedia.caption: Pulse oximeters detect the amount of oxygen in the blood by shining light through the finger.

results.title: ‘Each Day Is Critical’: South Korea’s 11th-Hour Battle With Covid
results.abstract: Officials are racing to secure more I.C.U. beds after an explosion of infections caused a bottleneck of patients. If cases aren’t brought under control, the government may impose Level 3 restrictions for the first time in South Korea.

multimedia.caption: Construction of a temporary hospital ward outside the Seoul Medical Center in South Korea earlier this month.

results.title: In Mexico, Childbirth in Covid’s Shadow
results.abstract: Midwives and doctors struggle to help women give birth safely during the grim days of the pandemic.

results.title: The U.K. Coronavirus Variant: What We Know
results.abstract: A newly identified variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus appears to be more contagious than established ones. Here’s what scientists know.
results.byline: By Carl Zimmer and Benedict Carey

results.title: A Plan by Eastern States to Cap Tailpipe Emissions Gets Off to a Slow Start
results.abstract: Connecticut, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Washington, D.C., all announced they would join a cap-and-trade program for cars and trucks. But many bigger states have yet to join.
des_facet: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

multimedia.caption: Washington, D.C. joined Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island in the program, with eight other states signaling that they would keep discussing but not participate for now.

results.title: Climate Change Legislation Included in Coronavirus Relief Deal
results.abstract: The legislation calls for cutting the use of powerful planet-warming chemicals common in air-conditioners and refrigerators.
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: The legislation requires the nation’s chemical manufacturers to phase out the use of coolants called hydrofluorocarbons, powerful planet-warming chemicals used in air-conditioners and refrigerators

results.abstract: The president-elect said he has chosen a team that prioritizes making clean energy jobs and environmental protection a cornerstone of his economic plans.

results.title: Hang in There, Help Is on the Way
results.abstract: Times are tough now, but the end is in sight. If we hunker down, keep our families safe during the holidays and monitor our health at home, life will get better in the spring. Here’s how to get through it.

results.title: F.D.A. Authorizes Moderna Vaccine, Adding Millions of Doses to U.S. Supply
results.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration authorized a second coronavirus vaccine for emergency use, clearing the way for millions more Americans to be immunized next week.
results.byline: By Denise Grady, Abby Goodnough and Noah Weiland

multimedia.caption: Beginning Sunday, shipments totaling 5.9 million doses of the Moderna vaccine may be sent to rural areas, smaller hospitals and local health departments. The first shots are expected to be given Monday.

results.title: In Massachusetts, Inmates Will Be Among First to Get Vaccines

results.abstract: The stem cells in this vital fluid could save someone’s life, but it probably won’t be your child’s.
